docs.lead_paragraph: Authorities in the United States have subpoenaed the reinsurance arm of the French insurer AXA, the company said on Wednesday, as an investigation into questionable insurance deals gathers steam. AXA Re said that the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, and the Securities and Exchange Commission have demanded information on its 1998 deals with the United States insurer MBIA. AXA Re issued a statement saying that it had been notified of subpoenas concerning MBIA transactions related to the bankruptcy of a hospital group in Pennsylvania as well as other ''nontraditional products.''

headline.main: French Insurer Subpoenaed in U.S. Case

docs.abstract: New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer and Securities and Exchange Commission subpoena reinsurance arm of French insurer AXA for information concerning its 1998 deals with US insurer MBIA as investigation into questionable insurance deals grows (S)
docs.snippet: Authorities in the U.S. have subpoenaed the reinsurance arm of the French insurer AXA, as an investigation into questionable insurance deals gathers steam.

docs.lead_paragraph: The revised budget that the State Legislature passed just before midnight on Tuesday includes about half of the $1.1 billion in cuts to Medicaid expenses that Gov. George E. Pataki sought in his budget proposal in January. It sets up a preferred-drug list that aides to Mr. Pataki said would save New York $60 million this year and up to $200 million next year by using the state's buying power in the open market to urge companies to offer lower prices for generic drugs. It increases a tax on nursing homes, with an eye toward forcing them to cut costs of their own. And it aligns benefits in Family Health Plus, the program that provides health coverage for the working poor, to resemble those given to state workers.

headline.main: Pataki and the Legislature Win Partial Victories in the Budget Fight Over Medicaid

docs.abstract: New York State Legislature passes revised budget that includes about half of $1.1 billion in Medicaid cuts sought by Gov George E Pataki; Medicaid swallows up more than 40 percent of budget; bill sets up preferred-drug list that Pataki aides say will save state $60 million in 2005 budget and $200 million in 2006 budget; increases tax on nursing homes, hoping to force them to cut costs on their own; aligns benefits in Family Health Plus program for working poor to resemble those given to state workers; budget is passed so quickly with so little public review that interested parties are continuing to weigh complicated fiscal implications; cuts represent $545.7 million in cost savings to Medicaid's $45 billion budget (M)
docs.snippet: The revised budget that the State Legislature passed just before midnight on Tuesday includes about half of the cuts to Medicaid expenses that Gov. George E. Pataki sought in his budget proposal.

docs.lead_paragraph: The City Council wants to hire 1,000 more police officers, reduce taxes on most businesses and restore millions of dollars that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposes to cut from cultural programs and social services next year, according to an alternative budget plan being put forward by the Council. The election-year plan, to be announced today by Speaker Gifford Miller, a Democratic candidate for mayor, would also include money for more teachers and double an earned-income tax credit for the working poor, said Council officials familiar with the details.

headline.main: Council to Counter Mayor's Budget With Tax-Break Plan

docs.abstract: New York City Council proposes to restore $286 million for cultural programs and social services that were cut by Mayor Michael R Bloomberg from proposed budget; Council's plan is to be announced by Speaker Gifford Miller, a Democratic candidate for mayor; plan anticipates $800 million in additional tax revenues in 2005 and 2006, making it possible to restore $276 million to Bloomberg's $48.3 billion budget; Council would also use $350 million to pay off city's debt; also proposes to scale back corporation tax exemption now granted to insurance companies, raising additional $195 million; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The election-year plan, to be announced Thursday by Speaker Gifford Miller, a Democratic candidate for mayor, anticipates $800 million in additional tax revenue this year and next.

docs.lead_paragraph: The battle over the Pentagon's billions has traditionally been fought between two forces -- those who want more new planes and ships and tanks, and those who want more money for troops. Now there is a third: military health care. The cost of the main military health care plan, Tricare, has doubled since 2001 and will soon reach $50 billion a year, more than a tenth of the Pentagon's budget. At least 75 percent of the benefits will go to veterans and retirees.

headline.main: A New Call to Arms: Military Health Care

docs.abstract: Battling is brewing in Congress on cost of main military health plan, Tricare, that has doubled since 2001 and will soon reach $50 billion a year, more than tenth of Pentagon's budget; at least 75 percent of benefits will go to veterans and retirees; over next decade, plan for military retirees, Tricare for Life, will cost at least $100 billion, rivaling costs of biggest weapons systems Pentagon is building; Pentagon supporters say military should not be pressed to choose between weapons and health care; Sen John W Warner says Congress will have to ask Pres Bush for money for health care program; graphs (M)
docs.snippet: Like corporate America, squeezed by the costs of health plans and pensions for graying workers, the military is recoiling at the costs of keeping promises to its people.

docs.lead_paragraph: Silicone breast implants made by a California company should be available to women who undergo cosmetic breast surgery, a federal advisory panel voted on Wednesday, rejecting arguments about serious health problems. The panel chairman called the 7-to-2 vote to approve an application by the company, the Mentor Corporation, unexpected.

headline.main: F.D.A. PANEL BACKS BREAST IMPLANTS FROM ONE MAKER

docs.abstract: Federal advisory panel votes to approve silicone breast implants from Mentor Corp day after it rejected similar application from Inamed Corp; most panel members say they are comfortable with long-term safety of Mentor devices, and most dismiss concerns that ruptured implants cause kind of serious diseases that some women's groups have listed; diverging votes send mixed message to Food and Drug Adm, making predictions about what it would decide impossible; many experts say FDA has toughened oversight of device and drug manufacturers in recent months; agency generally follows advice of its advisory panels; three-day hearing on implants included more than 160 witnesses, including dozens of women who claim implants sickened them and dozens of other women who pronounce silicone implants safe boost to their self-esteem; nearly all studies have found no link between silicone implants and serious disease (M)
docs.snippet: The panel voted to approve silicone implants made by Mentor Corporation, rejecting arguments about health problems.

byline.original: By GARDINER HARRIS; Barnaby J. Feder contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: LAURIE CONNEALY'S face showed all the signs of skin damage anyone might expect from years of sun worshiping: brown spots, red patches, squiggly broken capillaries and more wrinkles around her eyes and mouth than a woman her age has to have. To remove all this sun damage, Ms. Connealy, 46, a schoolteacher in Houston, would have been a perfect candidate for a facial peel with a laser or a chemical solution. But she was unwilling to face the weeklong recovery from the inevitable redness and swelling. Her dermatologist tried milder laser treatments, but they were ineffective.

headline.main: New Laser Promises Gentler Repairs For Damaged Skin

docs.snippet: A new skin resurfacing laser, which offers more benefits than a traditional laser peel, is gaining in popularity among patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: As this year's tax season winds down, frustrated business owners may be tempted to look for outside help to handle their paperwork, and not just for their future tax forms. But specialists warn they should be judicious about whom they hire to do the job. Service providers capable of taking over the task fall into two main categories. The first is payroll-service firms, which issue checks and take care of federal and state tax obligations. When using such a service, the business owner remains the taxpayer of record and retains all responsibility for taxes owed.

headline.main: The Perils of Hiring Out the Company's Paperwork

docs.abstract: Article on pitfalls that may occur when small business owners hire professional employer organizations (PEO's) to handle paperwork; PEO's are responsible for taxes, workers' compensation and benefits packages and often provide management training; businesses maintain day-to-day oversight and retain some responsibilities; examples of business owners who have been embezzled by unscrupulous PEO's discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Specialists warn that business owners should be judicious about whom they hire to handle their paperwork.

docs.lead_paragraph: Rodney Adler, a former director of HIH Insurance, became the first person imprisoned over the insurer's collapse, Australia's biggest corporate failure. He was sentenced to four and a half years in jail. Mr. Adler, 45, pleaded guilty to four charges, including two of making false statements intended to induce others to buy shares in HIH, a property and casualty insurer.
docs.abstract: Rodney Adler, former director of HIH Insurance, becomes first person imprisoned over insurer's collapse; pleads guilty to four charges, including two of making false statements intended to induce others to buy shares in HIH; must serve at least two and half years in jail before being eligible for parole (S)
docs.snippet: Rodney Adler, a former director of HIH Insurance Ltd., became the first person imprisoned over the insurer's collapse, Australia's biggest corporate failure.

docs.lead_paragraph: Twelve days after they passed New York's first on-time budget in 21 years, state lawmakers and Gov. George E. Pataki changed important provisions of the plan on Tuesday night after secret negotiations among the state's leaders. The revised budget was an unexpected coda to what many thought was a year of remarkable progress in the capital when lawmakers used public, bipartisan negotiations to pass a budget by the March 31 deadline, in daylight, with much fanfare.

headline.main: In Secret Talks, Leaders Revise Albany Budget

docs.abstract: New York State legislative leaders and Gov George Pataki, in secret talks, change key provisions of spending plan, twelve days after passing state's first on-time budget in 21 years; lawmakers used public, bipartisan negotiations to enact budget in daylight, with much fanfare; new deal is reversion to form, requiring members of Legislature to wait into night for bills to be printed after their leaders strike deal in private; photo; Pataki had threatened dozens of vetoes over spending, but ends up accepting most of estimated $106.6-billion plan that restores key programs (M)
docs.snippet: State lawmakers and Gov. George E. Pataki changed key provisions of New York's budget on Tuesday night after secret negotiations among the state's leaders.

byline.original: By AL BAKER and MICHAEL COOPER

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: MEDICARE will begin paying for prescription drugs on Jan. 1 next year. But between now and then, beneficiaries will have to cope with a flood of advertising, sort through a potentially confusing array of options and select a prescription drug plan before they can receive the benefit. For older and disabled people who now pay the full price of their medicines without any insurance coverage, the new benefit will almost surely be worthwhile, experts say. The same is probably true for beneficiaries who purchase supplementary coverage to fill gaps in Medicare.

headline.main: Get Ready: Medicare Drug Plan's To-Do List

docs.snippet: Beneficiaries must now sort through a potentially confusing array of options in order to select a prescription drug plan before they can receive the benefit.
